Graphical abstract Use oxide-supported catalyst in green solvent, hot water: Au is anchored on oxide via Au┄O-M interaction (M = Fe, Ti, etc). Basic aqueous catalytic system may destruct a part of OM bonds into oxygen vacancies and weaken Au/support interaction, causing leaching and aggregation of Au. Three simple methods synergistically improve reusability of catalyst. Obtaining reusable catalysts and using water as a green solvent still remain huge challenges. Various oxides are frequently used as the support, however, the aqueous catalytic systems, particularly in hot basic water, may decrease their stability and thus cause leaching or aggregation of the supported metal nanoparticles (NPs). In this work, three very simple methods in catalyst preparation are demonstrated to greatly improve the reusability of oxide-supported catalysts in 100 °C basic water, by systematically studying a series of oxides as well as carbons as support of gold (Au) NPs and employing Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling (SMCC) reaction as a probe. These methods are prerequisites for obtaining both excellent activity and recyclability. Absence of any of them will badly improve leaching or aggregation of Au NPs. The reasons for the synergistically improved reusability are also elucidated in details. Though it’s extremely hard to thoroughly overcome leaching in hot water, this work achieves the application of Au/oxide to SMCC reaction in water with higher utilization efficiency of Au than some reported work in organic solvent or with other supports. The present work can serve as supplementary strategies to assist in designing high-performance oxide-supported catalysts for varieties of similar aqueous systems. Keywords Catalyst reusability Water solvent Oxide support Metal nanoparticles Leaching 1 Introduction Various oxides, such as TiO2, Fe2O3, SiO2 or Al2O3, are one type of the most common support materials and have been widely employed to support the nanoparticles (NPs) of many different metals. At the same time, oxide-supported metal NPs are frequently used to catalyze the reactions in water. It’s well-known that utilizing water as the solvent is highly encouraged nowadays, in view of the points of green chemistry. Besides environmental benign, water also enables the good dissolution of inorganic bases. Bases are required by many catalytic reactions, such as Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling (SMCC) reaction [1–4]. Currently, basic water is a widely used catalytic system. Unfortunately, although oxide-supported nano-metal catalysts are applicable to such a catalytic system, the basic aqueous catalytic conditions can decrease the stability of oxides and thus cause the leaching of the supported metal NPs. Up to now, obtaining sufficient reusability with oxide-supported catalysts in water is still of tremendous challenges, especially in hot basic water. In this work, the boost of the applicability of oxide-supported catalysts in hot basic water is explored. SMCC over oxide-supported gold (Au) NPs serves as the probe reaction. The Au NPs on various oxides are a kind of intensively studied catalysts. Although they have exhibited promising activity for a range of reactions, such as oxidation and hydrogenation [5–9], the SMCC over Au/oxide is seldom reported, without using water as the solvent. This is possibly owing to the easy leaching of Au in hot basic water, resulting in the unsatisfactory catalytic performance. To the best of our knowledge, only Au/MgO and Au/CaO were showed to efficiently catalyze SMCC with DMF as solvent at 120 °C [1]. The results of this work show that, through simultaneously employing three very simple ways in catalyst preparation, the oxide-supported catalysts can give excellent activity and reusability in hot basic water. The obtained catalytic performance in water at 100 °C is even far better than that of the reported very active Au/CaO or Au/MgO catalyst in DMF at 120 °C. The origin of the high catalytic performance, especially for the greatly improved reusability, is also well elucidated. The present work provides some critical findings for improving the performance of the aqueous catalytic systems using oxide-supported catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Five kinds of oxides, together with carbons, were investigated as the support of Au catalysts (summarized in Table 1 ). Each ordinary (bulk) material had its nano counterpart. The ordinary Fe2O3 (AR), Al2O3 (AR), SiO2 (AR) and TiO2 (98 %, CP) were all purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. The ordinary MgO (≥ 98 %, AR) and activated carbon (AC) were obtained from Tianjin Damao Chemical Reagent Factory, while the nano γ-Al2O3 (≤20 nm; 99.99 % metals basis), SiO2 (20 nm; 99.8 % metals basis) and α-Fe2O3 (30 nm; 99.5 % metals basis) were obtained from Aladdin. Other support materials were purchased from Macklin for 50 nm MgO (99.9 % metals basis), XFNANO for carbon nanotubes (CNTs), and Greagent for 40 nm anatase TiO2 (99.8 %, AR). 2.2 Preparation of Au catalysts Au NPs were supported on various oxides by deposition-precipitation method using urea as the precipitating agent (DPU method), adapted from the previously reported procedures of Zanella et al. [10] and our former colleagues3. Briefly, a 0.5 × 10−3 M aqueous solution of HAuCl4 (≥99.9 %, Admas-beta) was first prepared, corresponding to the nominal Au loading of 3 wt%. Then the powdered support was added and urea was dissolved (0.42 M) at 81 °C. The formed slurry was further mixed at 81 °C for 17 h. Subsequently, it was filtered and washed with water until the filtrate become neutral. After dried, the obtained catalyst was calcined in air at different temperatures for 4 h with the heating rate of 2 °C/min. The Au/C catalysts were prepared by in-situ reduction method. Typically, the carbon materials were added to deionized water. After the above suspension was scattered uniformly by ultrasonic dispersion for 2 min, HAuCl4 aqueous solution was added and stirred for a further 30 min. Then freshly prepared aqueous solution of 0.1 M NaBH4 was added to reduce HAuCl4 under vigorous stirring. The solution was stirred for a further 30 min to complete the reaction. The resulting Au/C catalysts were separated from the reaction solution by centrifugation, and then were washed with water. Notation: Au/oxide-nm/number or Au/oxide-or/number: ‘oxide-nm’, ‘oxide-or’ and ‘number’ mean nano oxide, ordinary bulk oxide, and the calcination temperature of catalyst (°C), respectively. For example, ‘Au/TiO2-nm/650’ means the Au catalyst using nano TiO2 as the support and calcined at 650 °C. 2.3 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured with a D8 diffractometer (Bruker, Germany) with CuKa radiation at the step length of 0.05°/s. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Fourier transform infrared spectrometer. The average particle size of various ordinary support materials was determined on a BT-9300S laser particle size analyzer (Dandong Bettersize Instruments Ltd., Dandong, China). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed with a PHI Quantera SXM™ scanning X-ray Microprobe™ spectrometer. The binding energy was corrected using C1 s core line as reference. Raman spectra were recorded on a Raman inVia-Reflex microscopy system (Renishaw, Wotton-under-Edge, UK) equipped with a He-Ne laser as the excitation source (633 nm, 17 mW). Au loading of various catalysts were determined by a novAA350 atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) (Analytikjena, Jena, Germany). High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were obtained on a JEOL JEM 2100 F transmission electron microscope. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) as well as CO2 and NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2- and NH3-TPD) analyses were carried out by using a chemisorption analyzer (Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ-C chemisorption) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) to detect H2, NH3 and CO2 consumption. In each test, 0.1 g sample was used. Before H2-TPR measurement, the fresh sample was first pretreated in N2 at 400 °C for 0.5 h and cooled to 50 °C. Subsequently, the sample was heated in a 5 % H2/N2 gas mixture (15 mL/min) from 50 to 800 °C (10 °C min−1). In NH3-TPD test, after a 0.5 h pretreatment in He at 400 °C and a subsequent cooling to 50 °C, the sample underwent NH3 saturation with anhydrous 5 % NH3/He (15 mL/min) for 40 min. Then, the NH3-saturated sample was heated from 50 to 800 °C at a constant heating rate of 10 °C min−1. CO2- and NH3-TPD tests were similar. The main difference was the replacement of NH3 by CO2 gas. The effective surface charges (zeta potential) were measured using a Zetasizer Nano ZS90 (Malvern Instruments, UK). Samples were measured at 25 °C. 2.4 General procedure for Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling (SMCC) reaction SMCC reaction was carried out using water as the solvent. Typically, 2.0 mmol iodobenzene (≥99 %, RG, Adamas), 3.0 mmol phenylboronic acid (≥98 %, RG, Adamas) and K3PO4 (4.0 mmol) were added to 3 mL distilled water containing 40 mg Au catalysts. The resultant mixture was allowed to react under stirring at 100 °C for 2 h. After reaction, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and then was extracted with 10.0 ml ethyl acetate. The obtained extracts were analyzed by GC–MS. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 General characterization of Au catalysts The XRD results in Figs. 1 and S1 show that the ordinary bulk oxide supports, SiO2, α-Fe2O3, TiO2 and MgO, display much narrower diffraction peaks than their nano counterparts, indicative of the small sized and poorly crystallized features of nano supports. SiO2 is particularly typical. As shown in Fig. 1a, the ordinary SiO2 shows many narrow peaks, while its nano counterpart only shows a very broad peak around 2θ = 22.5°. Both nano and ordinary γ-Al2O3 display some broad peaks (Fig. 1b), which indicates that Al2O3 is amorphous in nature. Usually, the peaks for Au can be observed when using some not well-crystallized supports like SiO2 (Fig. 1a) and Al2O3 (Fig. 1b; the peaks of Au and Al2O3 may be overlapped, but Au/Al2O3 exhibits an intensified peak at 2θ = 38.3° as compared with Al2O3, confirming the deposition of Au on Al2O3). It is very hard to observe the peaks of Au with Au/TiO2 and Au/α-Fe2O3 (Fig. 1c and d) because of the either low content or high dispersion of Au [11,12]. Small NPs can exceed the detection limit of diffractometer. In the FT-IR spectra (Fig. 2 ), the characteristic bands are mainly from various support materials, roughly attributable to either hydroxyl or OM bonds (M = Si, Ti and Fe, etc.). Generally, nano supports and their bulk counterparts are different in the shape of the bands associated with OM bonds, such as the OFe (Fig. 2d) and OTi (Fig. 2e and f) bonds in the region of ∼1000−400 cm−1, which demonstrates the different OM bonds between nano and bulk supports. 3.2 Catalytic properties of the Au NPs on various supports As mentioned above, in organic DMF solvent Au/MgO and Au/CaO are reported to be very active for SMCC reaction, while the Au catalysts using a series of other metal-oxide supports, such as Al2O3, TiO2 and Fe2O3, show poor activity. [1] For example, Au/MgO or Au/CaO gave ∼90 % yield at 120 °C for 8 h, while Au/TiO2 and Au/Fe2O3 gave low yield even when the reaction time was prolonged to 20 h (Entry 2, Table 2 ). As the reaction requires the presence of a base, it was thus supposed that the high activity of Au/MgO and Au/CaO is most probably attributed to the high basicity of the supports. Due to the best performance of Au/MgO catalyst, its activity in water is first investigated. Au/CaO is not studied, as Au/CaO cannot exist in water due to the hydration of CaO to soluble Ca(OH)2 (Actually, Au/MgO also undergoes this situation, just the situation being not so badly. Solubility in water at 100 °C: 0.66 g/L for Ca(OH)2, 0.04 g/L for Mg(OH)2.). From Entries 1 and 2, Table 3 it can be seen that the use of both nano and ordinary MgO as the support gives poor catalytic activity in water. When MgO is replaced by SiO2, also no good activity can be obtained (Entries 3 and 4). The reasons can be attributed to the instability/reactivity of these oxides in basic aqueous catalytic system, resulting in the leaching of Au. As shown in Figs. 1a and 2 a, the support structure of Au/SiO2 catalysts was markedly changed after catalytic reaction, with the disappearance of Au (Figs. 1a and S2). Such situation is also suitable for Au/γ-Al2O3 and Au/MgO catalysts (Figs. 1b, 2 b and c and S1). Particularly, almost all the Au on various MgO was leached out after only one run, as shown by AAS analysis (Table S1). Au/γ-Al2O3 catalysts are not that worse, but the performance is still unsatisfactory (Table S2). Surprisingly, Au/AC and Au/CNTs are inactive (Entry 7, Table 3). The convinced reason is unknown, maybe due to no suitable affinity between the used carbon supports and substrates. Actually, the Au/CNTs in this work exhibits the activity in the similar order of magnitude to some reported Au/carbon catalysts (Entries 3–7, Table 2). Because the focus of this work is on oxides, the reasons are not further studied. Differently, Fe2O3 and TiO2 show higher stability than MgO, SiO2 and Al2O3. As shown by XRD and FT-IR analyses (Figs. 1c and d and 2 d–f), no obvious structural changes are observed after catalytic reaction. Indeed, Au/TiO2 and Au/Fe2O3 exhibit remarkably improved activity in water (Entries 8–11, Table 3). They also give much higher or comparable activity, as compared with some reported Au and even widely used Pd catalysts or with the reactions in organic solvent [1,13–29] (Table 2). The reason might be attributed to the better dissolution of base in water than in organic solvents. In addition, the reaction benefits from the increase in reaction temperature and time (Fig. S3). At 100 °C, the reaction is slow after 2 h (Fig. S3b). Therefore, various catalysts are evaluated at 100 °C for 2 h in this work. No catalytic reactions occur in the absence of either phenylboronic acid or iodobenzene (Entries 12 and 13, Table 3), confirming the reaction via cross coupling, instead of homo coupling depicted in Scheme S1. Homo coupling seems intrinsically more difficult and requires more catalyst or longer reaction time (Table S3), as compared with SMCC reaction (Table 2). Sometimes, catalyst calcination may play important roles in catalysis [30]. In the present work, surprisingly all the Au catalysts without calcination are even inert (Entries 14 and 15, Table 3). XPS results suggest that the as-deposited Au NPs on the support bear metallic/cationic mixed chemical state (Fig. S4). Interestingly, more metallic Au forms with nano supports, in other words, more cationic Au sustains on ordinary supports, possibly because nano supports interact with Au more strongly and thus the bonds of the Au precursor as-deposited on support are weakened to dissociate. After calcination all the cationic Au is transformed into metallic state. Simultaneously, the morphology is changed from ca. 1.60 nm well-dispersed clusters (Fig. 3 ) to ca. 4.68 nm well-crystallized NPs (Fig. 4 ), indicative of well-crystallized Au(0) as the active species. When the ordinary supports are replaced by their nano counterparts, there is no obvious increase in the activity (Table 3). However, nano-sizing the support, accompanied by calcining catalyst at a moderately high temperature, can significantly improve the reusability (Fig. 5 ). But these two attempts are not enough. The use of TiO2 as the support is also necessary. Otherwise, the activity basically vanishes after 1∼2 runs (Fig. 5). While Au/TiO2-nm/650 can be reused without significant loss in the activity after five catalytic runs. 3.3 Plausible mechanism for the synergistically improved catalytic performance The above results show that the prerequisites for obtaining both good activity and recyclability are: 1) using TiO2 as the support, 2) nano-sizing the support, and 3) calcining the catalysts at a moderately high temperature. Any of them is indispensable. Obviously, all these prerequisites can modify support effect. As various TiO2- and Fe2O3-supported Au catalysts show similar activity in their first run, i.e., just the catalyst stability is different, it can rationally speculate two possible reasons for the worsened reusability: 1) diminishment of Au active species and 2) leaching of Au after reaction. To testify the two possibilities, XPS analysis was carried out. For Au/Fe2O3-or, the Au 4f scan reveals an Au 4f 5/2 and 4f 7/2 doublet at ∼87.90 and ∼84.20 eV separated by ∼3.7 eV (Fig. 6 a), confirming the Au in zero-valent (metallic) state [31]. In all the other catalysts, the Au is also in metallic state, but the binding energy of Au gets lower when replacing ordinary supports by their nano counterparts or replacing Fe2O3 by TiO2 (Fig. 6). This indicates a pronounced Au┄O-Ti or Au┄O-Fe interaction that causes Au to be negatively charged, which is consistent with our previous work [32]; simultaneously, TiO2 and nano supports interact with Au more strongly than Fe2O3 and ordinary supports, respectively. After catalytic reaction, the binding energy of elemental Au (Fig. S5) as well as O (discussed in details later), Ti (Fig. S6) or Fe (Fig. S7) from support all shift to much lower values, indicating that the catalytic system also negatively charges the catalysts. But there are no obvious differences in the chemical state when using the same support. These observations suggest that the decreased activity for the reused catalyst is not related to the chemical state of Au. After reaction, Au/TiO2-nm/650 exhibits the strongest Au XPS signal among all the catalysts (Fig. S5). It should be attributed to the badly leaching of Au in other catalysts, possibly only a small part of Au that interacts with support relatively strongly being left. AAS analysis confirms the occurrence of Au leaching after catalytic reaction, but the catalysts using nano supports, particularly with calcination at 650 °C, suffer the least leaching. Though it’s exceedingly difficult to overcome the leaching in hot water and the leaching is not solved thoroughly (Fig. S8), this work I) realizes the application of Au/oxide in water with higher utilization efficiency of Au than some reported catalysts (Table 2 and S3), and II) can be employed as supplementary strategies to assist in designing high-performance catalysts for varieties of similar aqueous systems. Furthermore, HRTEM analysis suggests that the strongest Au/support interaction formed by Au/TiO2-nm/650 also prevents Au NPs from aggregation besides leaching, which explains why some reused catalysts with relatively low Au leaching exhibit very weak activity. As shown in Figs. 4, 7–9 , S9 and S10, depending on the support and calcination temperature of catalysts, in fresh catalysts the Au is deposited as ∼3.5–8.5 nm semi-spherical NPs contacting well with support. However, after catalytic reaction the Au NPs generally grow up into spheres of ∼ 20 nm or even far larger (Fig. S11-S14). While small Au NPs can still be observed with Au/TiO2-nm/650 (Fig. S15). Additionally, these Au NPs compactly cover the support, which might facilitate the isolation of water from the support underneath Au NPs. Thus, the three prerequisites for getting the great improved reusability should be attributed to the strong Au/support interactions that prevent Au from leaching and aggregation. The HRTEM analyses of Au/TiO2-nm (Figs. 3, 4 and 7) and Au/TiO2-or (Figs. 8 and 9) show that the calcination of catalysts causes the growth of Au NPs. This means that the Au/support interface for a single Au NP is enlarged, which is possibly a reason for the strengthened Au/support interaction by calcination. However, such an explanation is not enough, as there are no clear relations between Au particle size and Au/support interaction (reflected as anti-leaching or anti-aggregation). For example, with the increase in the calcination temperature from 400 to 650 °C, the average particle size of Au increases evidently from ∼3.68 to 8.44 nm for Au/TiO2-or (Figs. 8 and 9), while it increases from ∼4.68 to just ∼6.64 nm for Au/TiO2-nm (Figs. 4 and 7). In addition, Au/TiO2-or/650 exhibits bigger particles size than Au/TiO2-nm/650. However, the Au/support interaction is substantially improved with Au/TiO2-nm/650. Also, the Au NPs on ordinary (Fig. S9) and rod-like nano α-Fe2O3 (Fig. S10) show similar average particle size but with obviously different Au/support interaction. These observations suggest that Au atoms interact with the surface of nano support more strongly. The above suggestion is also in line with zeta potential analysis. As shown in Table 4 (Entry 2), the zeta potential of all the TiO2 and Fe2O3 supports is minus, indicative of the negatively charged surface. In addition, the bulk supports are more negatively charged than their nano counterparts. Parapat et al. [33] showed that the zeta potential of supports plays an important role in dispersing metal NPs during their deposition on the support, and in affecting NPs/support interaction. The support and metal NPs with an identical charge can repel each other. Thus, the NPs are more likely to migrate during calcination, increasing the tendency to agglomerate. On the contrary, if with opposite charges, the support and NPs will attract each other. This will favor the dispersion of NPs during their deposition on the support. Also, the NPs will be hard to migrate or loosen from the support. In the present work, the Au NPs are negatively charged, as shown by the XPS analysis (Fig. 6). This means that, the bulk supports, which are more negatively charged than their nano counterparts (Entry 2, Table 4), repel Au NPs more intensely and improve their tendency to migrate during high-temperature calcination. Indeed, the bulk supports lead to the formation of larger Au NPs if calcining catalyst at a higher temperature (Entry 3), or more evidently increased particle size of Au NPs when increasing the calcination temperature from 400 to 650 °C (4.76 nm with bulk TiO2 versus just 1.96 nm with nano TiO2; Entry 5). Moreover, in this work the Au NPs were deposited from HAuCl4 precursor, i.e., cationic Au. This may be a reason for the better deposition of Au NPs on the more negatively charged bulk TiO2 for the catalysts calcined at a relatively low temperature (Entry 4). But calcination indeed might strengthen the Au/support interaction, possibly due to more compact Au/support contact. This is supported by H2-TPR analysis, an effective tool that has been successfully used to verify strong metal/support interaction [34,35]. As shown in Fig. 10 a, a large H2-consumption peak centered around 650 °C, assigned to the reduction of Ti4+ to Ti3+ [34], can be observed with Au/TiO2-nm, while Au/TiO2-or shows no obvious H2 consumption, indicating a stronger Au┄O-Ti interaction in Au/TiO2-nm. In addition, improving calcination temperature slightly enlarges the H2-consumption peak of Au/TiO2-nm, suggestive of a closer Au/support interaction by calcining at 650 °C. This finding is also in accordance with the H2-TPR results of Au/α-Fe2O3-nm. In the profiles (Fig. 10b), the reduction peak located between 400 and 500 °C, due to Fe2O3 (hematite) → Fe3O4 (magnetite) transformation [35], is enlarged obviously when calcination temperature is enhanced from 400 to 650 °C. Table 5 suggests that the stronger Au/support interaction due to the calcination at 650 °C cannot be simply attributed to the change in the amount of surface acid/base sites. As shown in Entries 1–4, Table 5, with the increase in the calcination temperature from 400 to 650 °C, the amount of acid sites of Au/α-Fe2O3 is increased, while the amount of base sites is decreased. Au/TiO2 catalysts show a contrary trend (Entries 5–8, Table 5). Additionally, Au/TiO2-nm/650 and Au/TiO2-or/650 show almost the same amount of acid and base sites, but their catalytic performance is very different. There are no clear relations between catalytic properties and amount of acid/base sites. As the Au NPs are suggested to be anchored on the support mainly through the interaction with OM bonds (M = Ti or Fe), i.e., the bonds composing the bulk structure of the support, O 1s XPS analysis was performed to obtain more details. In the spectra (Fig. 11 ), two states of surface oxygen appear, commonly assigned to lattice oxygen (Oα) and oxygen vacancies (Oβ) [36–39]. The Oβ/Oα ratio can be used to evaluate the concentration of surface oxygen vacancies. For the fresh catalysts, Au/TiO2 exhibits much lower Oβ/Oα ratio than Au/Fe2O3 (Figs. 11 and 12 ), i.e., higher concentration of OM bonds on TiO2 surface, which is in line with the suggestion by the XPS analysis of Au that TiO2 interacts with Au more strongly than Fe2O3 (Fig. 6). After catalytic reaction, Oβ/Oα ratio increases distinctly for all the catalysts, but it increases less when using nano supports (Figs. 11 and 12); the order of Oβ/Oα ratio, i.e., Au/TiO2-nm < Au/TiO2-or ≈ Au/Fe2O3-nm < Au/Fe2O3-or, is opposite to the order in terms of catalyst recyclability, i.e., Au/TiO2-nm > Au/TiO2-or ≈ Au/Fe2O3-nm > Au/Fe2O3-or. This agrees with the suggestion that Au interacts with supports mainly through Au┄O-M interaction. Thus, the destruction of OM bonds due to Oα → Oβ transformation in basic aqueous catalytic system will weaken the Au/support interaction. However, nano supports more resist the damage in OM bonds and accordingly produce less oxygen vacancies than ordinary supports. This is also consistent with the FT-IR results that nano and ordinary supports possess different O–Ti or O–Fe bonds. The Raman analyses further suggest that the O–Ti bonds in nano TiO2 are stronger and thus more resists to damage. In Fig. 13 , the typical Raman active modes of anatase TiO2 can be observed. The strongest band around 150 cm−1 is attributed to the external vibration of O–Ti bond [40]. It shifts to higher wavenumbers (i.e., blue-shift) in Au/TiO2 as compared with that in pure TiO2 support, indicating strong interactions between Au and TiO2. Furthermore, nano TiO2 and its supported Au catalyst also show some blue shift, relative to their ordinary counterparts. Raman shift (Δν) is the wavenumber difference between Stokes scattered light (νs) and incident light (ν0). To explain these phenomena, the calculation of Raman band is simplified using a physical model-harmonic oscillator. The wavenumber (ν) is expressed by the following Hooke's law [40]: v(cm−1) = (k/μ)1/2/2πc Where c is the velocity of light, k is the bond force constant, and μ is the reduced mass. On the basis of the equation, the blue shift exhibited by nano TiO2 should be ascribed to the increased OTi bond force constant (k), which arises from the decreased OTi bond length. This is supported by bond order-length-strength (BOLS) correlation theory [41,42]. The core of the theory is the spontaneous contraction of lower-coordinated atoms, forming shorter-and-stronger bonds. Nano materials are typical materials with plentiful under-coordinated surface atoms. BOLS correlation theory has successfully reconciled and predicted the unusual behaviors of nano materials in thermal stability, mechanical strength, chemical reactivity, photon emissivity, etc. According to the observations of this work, the plausible mechanism for the synergistically improved reusability of Au/TiO2-nm/650 is schematically illustrated in Scheme 1 . The keys to obtaining high reusability in basic aqueous catalytic systems are the stabilization of oxide support plus a strong Au/support interaction, preventing Au NPs from leaching and aggregation. Some materials themselves, such as MgO and SiO2, are highly instable under such catalytic conditions so that they cannot maintain a stable Au/support interface. Differently, Fe2O3 and TiO2 show high stability. However, despite no obvious changes in bulk structure after catalytic reaction as observed from XRD and FT-IR analyses, there are still some structural change on support surface due to the destruction of a part of OM bonds (M = Ti or Fe) into oxygen vacancies. This can weaken the Au/support interaction, as the Au NPs are anchored on the support mainly by the Au┄OM interaction. But nano TiO2 with plentiful under-coordinated surface atoms possesses higher resistance to the damage in OM bonds than bulk TiO2 (right part of Scheme 1), according to BOLS correlation theory (forming shorter-and-stronger bonds due to the spontaneous contraction of lower-coordinated atoms [41,42]). On the other hand, using TiO2 of lower Oβ/Oα ratio than Fe2O3 as the support, calcining catalyst at a higher temperature, and employing nano oxides instead of bulk ones all can improve the Au/support interaction (left part of Scheme 1). These possibly also facilitate the isolation of water from the support within the Au/support interface, due to the more compact Au cover on the support. 4 Conclusions In summary, the stabilization of support materials under hot basic aqueous catalytic conditions, and a strong Au/support interaction are two keys to the reusability of oxide supported catalysts in hot basic water, which prevent Au NPs from leaching and aggregation. Three straightforward ways during catalyst preparation can reach a synergistically improved reusability: 1) using TiO2 of relatively low Oβ/Oα ratio as support, 2) nano-sizing support, and 3) calcining catalysts with a moderately high temperature (e.g., 650 °C instead of the commonly used ≤400 °C). Au/TiO2-nm/650 can be reused without significant loss in the activity after five catalytic runs. Absence of any of them will cause a poor reusability (the activity basically vanishes after 1∼2 runs), due to the decreased interaction of Au atoms with support surface. A plausible reason is as follows: the Au NPs are anchored on the support surface mainly through Au┄O-M interaction (M = Ti, Fe, etc), while the hot basic aqueous catalytic system can destruct a part of OM bonds into oxygen vacancies and thus weaken the Au/support interaction; nano-sizing TiO2 can strengthen OTi bonds, according to BOLS correlation theory. Such structural change on support surface explains why not all the TiO2 and Fe2O3 are suitable support, though they show higher stability than MgO, SiO2 and Al2O3 and even no obvious changes in bulk structure after catalytic reaction are observed by XRD and FT-IR analysis. Oxide-supported nano-metal catalysts are frequently used in aqueous catalytic systems. Although it’s highly difficult to completely overcome the leaching of metal NPs, especially in hot basic water, this work can be employed as supplementary measures in designing high-performance oxide-supported metal catalysts used in water. Another significance of this work is exploring the untapped SMCC ability of Au/oxide in water as a Pd alternative, which shows far higher activity than some work in organic solvents (maybe because base dissolves better in water) or with other supports like carbons. coredata.dc:description: Obtaining reusable catalysts and using water as a green solvent still remain huge challenges. Various oxides are frequently used as the support, however, the aqueous catalytic systems, particularly in hot basic water, may decrease their stability and thus cause leaching or aggregation of the supported metal nanoparticles (NPs). In this work, three very simple methods in catalyst preparation are demonstrated to greatly improve the reusability of oxide-supported catalysts in 100 °C basic water, by systematically studying a series of oxides as well as carbons as support of gold (Au) NPs and employing Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling (SMCC) reaction as a probe. These methods are prerequisites for obtaining both excellent activity and recyclability. Absence of any of them will badly improve leaching or aggregation of Au NPs. The reasons for the synergistically improved reusability are also elucidated in details. Though it’s extremely hard to thoroughly overcome leaching in hot water, this work achieves the application of Au/oxide to SMCC reaction in water with higher utilization efficiency of Au than some reported work in organic solvent or with other supports. The present work can serve as supplementary strategies to assist in designing high-performance oxide-supported catalysts for varieties of similar aqueous systems.
coredata.dc:title: Markedly improved performance of oxide-supported catalysts in hot basic water by three facile ways in synergy
